verses.text: After this must be reckoned the epistles of Paul; next in order the extant former epistle of John, and likewise the epistle of Peter, must be maintained.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 25:6
verses.text: After them is to be placed, if it really seem proper, the Apocalypse of John, concerning which we shall give the different opinions at the proper time.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 25:7
verses.text: These then belong among the accepted writings.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 25:8
verses.text: Among the disputed writings, which are nevertheless recognized by many, are extant the so-called epistle of James and that of Jude, also the second epistle of Peter, and those that are called the second and third of John, whether they belong to the evangelist or to another person of the same name.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 25:9
verses.text: Among the rejected writings must be reckoned also the Acts of Paul, and the so-called Shepherd, and the Apocalypse of Peter, and in addition to these the extant epistle of Barnabas, and the so-called Teachings of the Apostles; and besides, as I said, the Apocalypse of John, if it seem proper, which some, as I said, reject, but which others class with the accepted books.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 25:10
verses.text: And among these some have placed also the Gospel according to the Hebrews, with which those of the Hebrews that have accepted Christ are especially delighted.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 25:11
verses.text: And all these may be reckoned among the disputed books.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 25:12
verses.text: But we have nevertheless felt compelled to give a catalogue of these also, distinguishing those works which according to ecclesiastical tradition are true and genuine and commonly accepted, from those others which, although not canonical but disputed, are yet at the same time known to most ecclesiastical writers—we have felt compelled to give this catalogue in order that we might be able to know both these works and those that are cited by the heretics under the name of the apostles, including, for instance, such books as the Gospels of Peter, of Thomas, of Matthias, or of any others besides them, and the Acts of Andrew and John and the other apostles, which no one belonging to the succession of ecclesiastical writers has deemed worthy of mention in his writings.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 25:13
verses.text: And further, the character of the style is at variance with apostolic usage, and both the thoughts and the purpose of the things that are related in them are so completely out of accord with true orthodoxy that they clearly show themselves to be the fictions of heretics.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 25:14
verses.text: Wherefore they are not to be placed even among the rejected writings, but are all of them to be cast aside as absurd and impious.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 25:15
verses.text: Let us now proceed with our history.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 26:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVI.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 26:2
verses.text: —Menander the Sorcerer.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 26:3
verses.text: Menander, who succeeded Simon Magus, showed himself in his conduct another instrument of diabolical power, not inferior to the former.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 26:4
verses.text: He also was a Samaritan and carried his sorceries to no less an extent than his teacher had done, and at the same time reveled in still more marvelous tales than he.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 26:5
verses.text: For he said that he was himself the Saviour, who had been sent down from invisible aeons for the salvation of men; and he taught that no one could gain the mastery over the world-creating angels themselves unless he had first gone through the magical discipline imparted by him and had received baptism from him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 26:6
verses.text: Those who were deemed worthy of this would partake even in the present life of perpetual immortality, and would never die, but would remain here forever, and without growing old become immortal.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 26:7
verses.text: These facts can be easily learned from the works of Irenaeus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 26:8
verses.text: And Justin, in the passage in which he mentions Simon, gives an account of this man also, in the following words: "And we know that a certain Menander, who was also a Samaritan, from the village of Capparattea, was a disciple of Simon, and that he also, being driven by the demons, came to Antioch and deceived many by his magical art.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 26:9
verses.text: And he persuaded his followers that they should not die.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 26:10
verses.text: And there are still some of them that assert this".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 26:11
verses.text: And it was indeed an artifice of the devil to endeavor, by means of such sorcerers, who assumed the name of Christians, to defame the great mystery of godliness by magic art, and through them to make ridiculous the doctrines of the Church concerning the immortality of the soul and the resurrection of the dead.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 26:12
verses.text: But they that have chosen these men as their saviours have fallen away from the true hope.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 27:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 27:2
verses.text: —The Heresy of the Ebionites.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 27:3
verses.text: The evil demon, however, being unable to tear certain others from their allegiance to the Christ of God, yet found them susceptible in a different direction, and so brought them over to his own purposes.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 27:4
verses.text: The ancients quite properly called these men Ebionites, because they held poor and mean opinions concerning Christ.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 27:5
verses.text: For they considered him a plain and common man, who was justified only because of his superior virtue, and who was the fruit of the intercourse of a man with Mary.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 27:6
verses.text: In their opinion the observance of the ceremonial law was altogether necessary, on the ground that they could not be saved by faith in Christ alone and by a corresponding life.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 27:7
verses.text: There were others, however, besides them, that were of the same name, but avoided the strange and absurd beliefs of the former, and did not deny that the Lord was born of a virgin and of the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 27:8
verses.text: But nevertheless, inasmuch as they also refused to acknowledge that he pre-existed, being God, Word, and Wisdom, they turned aside into the impiety of the former, especially when they, like them, endeavored to observe strictly the bodily worship of the law.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 27:9
verses.text: These men, moreover, thought that it was necessary to reject all the epistles of the apostle, whom they called an apostate from the law; and they used only the so-called Gospel according to the Hebrews and made small account of the rest.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 27:10
verses.text: The Sabbath and the rest of the discipline of the Jews they observed just like them, but at the same time, like us, they celebrated the Lord's days as a memorial of the resurrection of the Saviour.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 27:11
verses.text: Wherefore, in consequence of such a course they received the name of Ebionites, which signified the poverty of their understanding.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 27:12
verses.text: For this is the name by which a poor man is called among the Hebrews.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 28:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVIII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 28:2
verses.text: —Cerinthus the Heresiarch.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 28:3
verses.text: We have understood that at this time Cerinthus, the author of another heresy, made his appearance.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 28:4
verses.text: Caius, whose words we quoted above, in the Disputation which is ascribed to him, writes as follows concerning this man:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 28:5
verses.text: "But Cerinthus also, by means of revelations which he pretends were written by a great apostle, brings before us marvelous things which he falsely claims were shown him by angels; and he says that after the resurrection the kingdom of Christ will be set up on earth, and that the flesh dwelling in Jerusalem will again be subject to desires and pleasures.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 28:6
verses.text: And being an enemy of the Scriptures of God, he asserts, with the purpose of deceiving men, that there is to be a period of a thousand years for marriage festivals".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 28:7
verses.text: And Dionysius, who was bishop of the parish of Alexandria in our day, in the second book of his work On the Promises, where he says some things concerning the Apocalypse of John which he draws from tradition, mentions this same man in the following words:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 28:8
verses.text: "But (they say that) Cerinthus, who founded the sect which was called, after him, the Cerinthian, desiring reputable authority for his fiction, prefixed the name.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 28:9
verses.text: For the doctrine which he taught was this: that the kingdom of Christ will be an earthly one.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 28:10
verses.text: And as he was himself devoted to the pleasures of the body and altogether sensual in his nature, he dreamed that that kingdom would consist in those things which he desired, namely, in the delights of the belly and of sexual passion, that is to say, in eating and drinking and marrying, and in festivals and sacrifices and the slaying of victims, under the guise of which he thought he could indulge his appetites with a better grace".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 28:11
verses.text: These are the words of Dionysius.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 28:12
verses.text: But Irenaeus, in the first book of his work Against Heresies, gives some more abominable false doctrines of the same man, and in the third book relates a story which deserves to be recorded.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 28:13
verses.text: He says, on the authority of Polycarp, that the apostle John once entered a bath to bathe; but, learning that Cerinthus was within, he sprang from the place and rushed out of the door, for he could not bear to remain under the same roof with him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 28:14
verses.text: And he advised those that were with him to do the same, saying, "Let us flee, lest the bath fall; for Cerinthus, the enemy of the truth, is within".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 29:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIX.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 29:2
verses.text: —Nicolaus and the Sect named after him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 29:3
verses.text: At this time the so-called sect of the Nicolaitans made its appearance and lasted for a very short time.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 29:4
verses.text: Mention is made of it in the Apocalypse of John.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 29:5
verses.text: They boasted that the author of their sect was Nicolaus, one of the deacons who, with Stephen, were appointed by the apostles for the purpose of ministering to the poor.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 29:6
verses.text: Clement of Alexandria, in the third book of his Stromata, relates the following things concerning him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 29:7
verses.text: "They say that he had a beautiful wife, and after the ascension of the Saviour, being accused by the apostles of jealousy, he led her into their midst and gave permission to any one that wished to marry her.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 29:8
verses.text: For they say that this was in accord with that saying of his, that one ought to abuse the flesh.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 29:9
verses.text: And those that have followed his heresy, imitating blindly and foolishly that which was done and said, commit fornication without shame.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 29:10
verses.text: But I understand that Nicolaus had to do with no other woman than her to whom he was married, and that, so far as his children are concerned, his daughters continued in a state of virginity until old age, and his son remained uncorrupt.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 29:11
verses.text: If this is so, when he brought his wife, whom he jealously loved, into the midst of the apostles, he was evidently renouncing his passion; and when he used the expression, 'to abuse the flesh,' he was inculcating self-control in the face of those pleasures that are eagerly pursued.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 29:12
verses.text: For I suppose that, in accordance with the command of the Saviour, he did not wish to serve two masters, pleasure and the Lord.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 29:13
verses.text: But they say that Matthias also taught in the same manner that we ought to fight against and abuse the flesh, and not give way to it for the sake of pleasure, but strengthen the soul by faith and knowledge".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 29:14
verses.text: So much concerning those who then attempted to pervert the truth, but in less time than it has taken to tell it became entirely extinct.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 30:1
verses.text: Chapter XXX.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 30:2
verses.text: —The Apostles that were Married.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 30:3
verses.text: Clement, indeed, whose words we have just quoted, after the above-mentioned facts gives a statement, on account of those who rejected marriage, of the apostles that had wives.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 30:4
verses.text: "Or will they," says he, "reject even the apostles? For Peter and Philip begat children; and Philip also gave his daughters in marriage.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 30:5
verses.text: And Paul does not hesitate, in one of his epistles, to greet his wife, whom he did not take about with him, that he might not be inconvenienced in his ministry".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 30:6
verses.text: And since we have mentioned this subject it is not improper to subjoin another account which is given by the same author and which is worth reading.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 30:7
verses.text: In the seventh book of his Stromata he writes as follows: "They say, accordingly, that when the blessed Peter saw his own wife led out to die, he rejoiced because of her summons and her return home, and called to her very encouragingly and comfortingly, addressing her by name, and saying, 'Oh thou, remember the Lord.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 30:8
verses.text: ' Such was the marriage of the blessed, and their perfect disposition toward those dearest to them".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 30:9
verses.text: This account being in keeping with the subject in hand, I have related here in its proper place.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 31:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXI.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 31:2
verses.text: —The Death of John and Philip.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 31:3
verses.text: The time and the manner of the death of Paul and Peter as well as their burial places, have been already shown by us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 31:4
verses.text: The time of John's death has also been given in a general way, but his burial place is indicated by an epistle of Polycrates (who was bishop of the parish of Ephesus), addressed to Victor, bishop of Rome.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 31:5
verses.text: In this epistle he mentions him together with the apostle Philip and his daughters in the following words:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 31:6
verses.text: "For in Asia also great lights have fallen asleep, which shall rise again on the last day, at the coming of the Lord, when he shall come with glory from heaven and shall seek out all the saints.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 31:7
verses.text: Among these are Philip, one of the twelve apostles, who sleeps in Hierapolis, and his two aged virgin daughters, and another daughter who lived in the Holy Spirit and now rests at Ephesus; and moreover John, who was both a witness and a teacher, who reclined upon the bosom of the Lord, and being a priest wore the sacerdotal plate.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 31:8
verses.text: He also sleeps at Ephesus".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 31:9
verses.text: So much concerning their death.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 31:10
verses.text: And in the Dialogue of Caius which we mentioned a little above, Proclus, against whom he directed his disputation, in agreement with what has been quoted, speaks thus concerning the death of Philip and his daughters: "After him there were four prophetesses, the daughters of Philip, at Hierapolis in Asia.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 31:11
verses.text: Their tomb is there and the tomb of their father".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 31:12
verses.text: Such is his statement.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 31:13
verses.text: But Luke, in the Acts of the Apostles, mentions the daughters of Philip who were at that time at Caesarea in Judea with their father, and were honored with the gift of prophecy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 31:14
verses.text: His words are as follows: "We came unto Caesarea; and entering into the house of Philip the evangelist, who was one of the seven, we abode with him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 31:15
verses.text: Now this man had four daughters, virgins, which did prophesy".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 31:16
verses.text: We have thus set forth in these pages what has come to our knowledge concerning the apostles themselves and the apostolic age, and concerning the sacred writings which they have left us, as well as concerning those which are disputed, but nevertheless have been publicly used by many in a great number of churches, and moreover, concerning those that are altogether rejected and are out of harmony with apostolic orthodoxy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 31:17
verses.text: Having done this, let us now proceed with our history.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 32:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 32:2
verses.text: —Symeon, Bishop of Jerusalem, suffers Martyrdom.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 32:3
verses.text: It is reported that after the age of Nero and Domitian, under the emperor whose times we are now recording, a persecution was stirred up against us in certain cities in consequence of a popular uprising.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 32:4
verses.text: In this persecution we have understood that Symeon, the son of Clopas, who, as we have shown, was the second bishop of the church of Jerusalem, suffered martyrdom.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 32:5
verses.text: Hegesippus, whose words we have already quoted in various places, is a witness to this fact also.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 32:6
verses.text: Speaking of certain heretics he adds that Symeon was accused by them at this time; and since it was clear that he was a Christian, he was tortured in various ways for many days, and astonished even the judge himself and his attendants in the highest degree, and finally he suffered a death similar to that of our Lord.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 32:7
verses.text: But there is nothing like hearing the historian himself, who writes as follows: "Certain of these heretics brought accusation against Symeon, the son of Clopas, on the ground that he was a descendant of David and a Christian; and thus he suffered martyrdom, at the age of one hundred and twenty years, while Trajan was emperor and Atticus governor".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 32:8
verses.text: And the same writer says that his accusers also, when search was made for the descendants of David, were arrested as belonging to that family.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 32:9
verses.text: And it might be reasonably assumed that Symeon was one of those that saw and heard the Lord, judging from the length of his life, and from the fact that the Gospel makes mention of Mary, the wife of Clopas, who was the father of Symeon, as has been already shown.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 32:10
verses.text: The same historian says that there were also others, descended from one of the so-called brothers of the Saviour, whose name was Judas, who, after they had borne testimony before Domitian, as has been already recorded, in behalf of faith in Christ, lived until the same reign.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 32:11
verses.text: He writes as follows: "They came, therefore, and took the lead of every church as witnesses and as relatives of the Lord.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 32:12
verses.text: And profound peace being established in every church, they remained until the reign of the Emperor Trajan, and until the above-mentioned Symeon, son of Clopas, an uncle of the Lord, was informed against by the heretics, and was himself in like manner accused for the same cause before the governor Atticus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 32:13
verses.text: And after being tortured for many days he suffered martyrdom, and all, including even the proconsul, marveled that, at the age of one hundred and twenty years, he could endure so much.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 32:14
verses.text: And orders were given that he should be crucified".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 32:15
verses.text: In addition to these things the same man, while recounting the events of that period, records that the Church up to that time had remained a pure and uncorrupted virgin, since, if there were any that attempted to corrupt the sound norm of the preaching of salvation, they lay until then concealed in obscure darkness.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 32:16
verses.text: But when the sacred college of apostles had suffered death in various forms, and the generation of those that had been deemed worthy to hear the inspired wisdom with their own ears had passed away, then the league of godless error took its rise as a result of the folly of heretical teachers, who, because none of the apostles was still living, attempted henceforth, with a bold face, to proclaim, in opposition to the preaching of the truth, the 'knowledge which is falsely so-called.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 33:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXIII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 33:2
verses.text: —Trajan forbids the Christians to be sought after.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 33:3
verses.text: So great a persecution was at that time opened against us in many places that Plinius Secundus, one of the most noted of governors, being disturbed by the great number of martyrs, communicated with the emperor concerning the multitude of those that were put to death for their faith.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 33:4
verses.text: At the same time, he informed him in his communication that he had not heard of their doing anything profane or contrary to the laws,—except that they arose at dawn and sang hymns to Christ as a God; but that they renounced adultery and murder and like criminal offenses, and did all things in accordance with the laws.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 33:5
verses.text: In reply to this Trajan made the following decree: that the race of Christians should not be sought after, but when found should be punished.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 33:6
verses.text: On account of this the persecution which had threatened to be a most terrible one was to a certain degree checked, but there were still left plenty of pretexts for those who wished to do us harm.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 33:7
verses.text: Sometimes the people, sometimes the rulers in various places, would lay plots against us, so that, although no great persecutions took place, local persecutions were nevertheless going on in particular provinces, and many of the faithful endured martyrdom in various forms.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 33:8
verses.text: We have taken our account from the Latin Apology of Tertullian which we mentioned above.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 33:9
verses.text: The translation runs as follows: "And indeed we have found that search for us has been forbidden.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 33:10
verses.text: For when Plinius Secundus, the governor of a province, had condemned certain Christians and deprived them of their dignity, he was confounded by the multitude, and was uncertain what further course to pursue.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 33:11
verses.text: He therefore communicated with Trajan the emperor, informing him that, aside from their unwillingness to sacrifice, he had found no impiety in them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 33:12
verses.text: And he reported this also, that the Christians arose early in the morning and sang hymns unto Christ as a God, and for the purpose of preserving their discipline forbade murder, adultery, avarice, robbery, and the like.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 33:13
verses.text: In reply to this Trajan wrote that the race of Christians should not be sought after, but when found should be punished".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 33:14
verses.text: Such were the events which took place at that time.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 34:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXIV.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 34:2
verses.text: —Evarestus, the Fourth Bishop of the Church of Rome.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 34:3
verses.text: In the third year of the reign of the emperor mentioned above, Clement committed the episcopal government of the church of Rome to Evarestus, and departed this life after he had superintended the teaching of the divine word nine years in all.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 35:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXV.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 35:2
verses.text: —Justus, the Third Bishop of Jerusalem.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 35:3
verses.text: But when Symeon also had died in the manner described, a certain Jew by the name of Justus succeeded to the episcopal throne in Jerusalem.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 35:4
verses.text: He was one of the many thousands of the circumcision who at that time believed in Christ.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXVI.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:2
verses.text: —Ignatius and His Epistles.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:3
verses.text: At that time Polycarp, a disciple of the apostles, was a man of eminence in Asia, having been entrusted with the episcopate of the church of Smyrna by those who had seen and heard the Lord.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:4
verses.text: And at the same time Papias, bishop of the parish of Hierapolis, became well known, as did also Ignatius, who was chosen bishop of Antioch, second in succession to Peter, and whose fame is still celebrated by a great many.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:5
verses.text: Report says that he was sent from Syria to Rome, and became food for wild beasts on account of his testimony to Christ.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:6
verses.text: And as he made the journey through Asia under the strictest military surveillance, he fortified the parishes in the various cities where he stopped by oral homilies and exhortations, and warned them above all to be especially on their guard against the heresies that were then beginning to prevail, and exhorted them to hold fast to the tradition of the apostles.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:7
verses.text: Moreover, he thought it necessary to attest that tradition in writing, and to give it a fixed form for the sake of greater security.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:8
verses.text: So when he came to Smyrna, where Polycarp was, he wrote an epistle to the church of Ephesus, in which he mentions Onesimus, its pastor; and another to the church of Magnesia, situated upon the Maeander, in which he makes mention again of a bishop Damas; and finally one to the church of Tralles, whose bishop, he states, was at that time Polybius.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:9
verses.text: In addition to these he wrote also to the church of Rome, entreating them not to secure his release from martyrdom, and thus rob him of his earnest hope.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:10
verses.text: In confirmation of what has been said it is proper to quote briefly from this epistle.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:11
verses.text: He writes as follows: "From Syria even unto Rome I fight with wild beasts, by land and by sea, by night and by day, being bound amidst ten leopards that is, a company of soldiers who only become worse when they are well treated.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:12
verses.text: In the midst of their wrongdoings, however, I am more fully learning discipleship, but I am not thereby justified.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:13
verses.text: May I have joy of the beasts that are prepared for me; and I pray that I may find them ready; I will even coax them to devour me quickly that they may not treat me as they have some whom they have refused to touch through fear.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:14
verses.text: And if they are unwilling, I will compel them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:15
verses.text: Forgive me.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:16
verses.text: I know what is expedient for me.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:17
verses.text: Now do I begin to be a disciple.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:18
verses.text: May naught of things visible and things invisible envy me; that I may attain unto Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:19
verses.text: Let fire and cross and attacks of wild beasts, let wrenching of bones, cutting of limbs, crushing of the whole body, tortures of the devil,—let all these come upon me if only I may attain unto Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:20
verses.text: These things he wrote from the above-mentioned city to the churches referred to.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:21
verses.text: And when he had left Smyrna he wrote again from Troas to the Philadelphians and to the church of Smyrna; and particularly to Polycarp, who presided over the latter church.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:22
verses.text: And since he knew him well as an apostolic man, he commended to him, like a true and good shepherd, the flock at Antioch, and besought him to care diligently for it.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:23
verses.text: And the same man, writing to the Smyrnaeans, used the following words concerning Christ, taken I know not whence: "But I know and believe that he was in the flesh after the resurrection.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:24
verses.text: And when he came to Peter and his companions he said to them, Take, handle me, and see that I am not an incorporeal spirit.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:25
verses.text: And immediately they touched him and believed".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:26
verses.text: Irenaeus also knew of his martyrdom and mentions his epistles in the following words: "As one of our people said, when he was condemned to the beasts on account of his testimony unto God, I am God's wheat, and by the teeth of wild beasts am I ground, that I may be found pure bread".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:27
verses.text: Polycarp also mentions these letters in the epistle to the Philippians which is ascribed to him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:28
verses.text: His words are as follows: "I exhort all of you, therefore, to be obedient and to practice all patience such as ye saw with your own eyes not only in the blessed Ignatius and Rufus and Zosimus, but also in others from among yourselves as well as in Paul himself and the rest of the apostles; being persuaded that all these ran not in vain, but in faith and righteousness, and that they are gone to their rightful place beside the Lord, with whom also they suffered.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:29
verses.text: For they loved not the present world, but him that died for our sakes and was raised by God for us".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:30
verses.text: And afterwards he adds: "You have written to me, both you and Ignatius, that if any one go to Syria he may carry with him the letters from you.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:31
verses.text: And this I will do if I have a suitable opportunity, either I myself or one whom I send to be an ambassador for you also.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:32
verses.text: The epistles of Ignatius which were sent to us by him and the others which we had with us we sent to you as you gave charge.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:33
verses.text: They are appended to this epistle, and from them you will be able to derive great advantage.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:34
verses.text: For they comprise faith and patience, and every kind of edification that pertaineth to our Lord".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:35
verses.text: So much concerning Ignatius.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 36:36
verses.text: But he was succeeded by Heros in the episcopate of the church of Antioch.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 37:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXVII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 37:2
verses.text: —The Evangelists that were still Eminent at that Time.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 37:3
verses.text: Among those that were celebrated at that time was Quadratus, who, report says, was renowned along with the daughters of Philip for his prophetical gifts.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 37:4
verses.text: And there were many others besides these who were known in those days, and who occupied the first place among the successors of the apostles.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 37:5
verses.text: And they also, being illustrious disciples of such great men, built up the foundations of the churches which had been laid by the apostles in every place, and preached the Gospel more and more widely and scattered the saving seeds of the kingdom of heaven far and near throughout the whole world.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 37:6
verses.text: For indeed most of the disciples of that time, animated by the divine word with a more ardent love for philosophy, had already fulfilled the command of the Saviour, and had distributed their goods to the needy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 37:7
verses.text: Then starting out upon long journeys they performed the office of evangelists, being filled with the desire to preach Christ to those who had not yet heard the word of faith, and to deliver to them the divine Gospels.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 37:8
verses.text: And when they had only laid the foundations of the faith in foreign places, they appointed others as pastors, and entrusted them with the nurture of those that had recently been brought in, while they themselves went on again to other countries and nations, with the grace and the co-operation of God.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 37:9
verses.text: For a great many wonderful works were done through them by the power of the divine Spirit, so that at the first hearing whole multitudes of men eagerly embraced the religion of the Creator of the universe.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 37:10
verses.text: But since it is impossible for us to enumerate the names of all that became shepherds or evangelists in the churches throughout the world in the age immediately succeeding the apostles, we have recorded, as was fitting, the names of those only who have transmitted the apostolic doctrine to us in writings still extant.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 38:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXVIII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 38:2
verses.text: —The Epistle of Clement and the Writings falsely ascribed to him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 38:3
verses.text: Thus Ignatius has done in the epistles which we have mentioned, and Clement in his epistle which is accepted by all, and which he wrote in the name of the church of Rome to the church of Corinth.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 38:4
verses.text: In this epistle he gives many thoughts drawn from the Epistle to the Hebrews, and also quotes verbally some of its expressions, thus showing most plainly that it is not a recent production.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 38:5
verses.text: Wherefore it has seemed reasonable to reckon it with the other writings of the apostle.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 38:6
verses.text: For as Paul had written to the Hebrews in his native tongue, some say that the evangelist Luke, others that this Clement himself, translated the epistle.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 38:7
verses.text: The latter seems more probable, because the epistle of Clement and that to the Hebrews have a similar character in regard to style, and still further because the thoughts contained in the two works are not very different.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 38:8
verses.text: But it must be observed also that there is said to be a second epistle of Clement.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 38:9
verses.text: But we do not know that this is recognized like the former, for we do not find that the ancients have made any use of it.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 38:10
verses.text: And certain men have lately brought forward other wordy and lengthy writings under his name, containing dialogues of Peter and Apion.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 38:11
verses.text: But no mention has been made of these by the ancients; for they do not even preserve the pure stamp of apostolic orthodoxy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 38:12
verses.text: The acknowledged writing of Clement is well known.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 38:13
verses.text: We have spoken also of the works of Ignatius and Polycarp.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXIX.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:2
verses.text: —The Writings of Papias.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:3
verses.text: There are extant five books of Papias, which bear the title Expositions of Oracles of the Lord.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:4
verses.text: Irenaeus makes mention of these as the only works written by him, in the following words: "These things are attested by Papias, an ancient man who was a hearer of John and a companion of Polycarp, in his fourth book.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:5
verses.text: For five books have been written by him".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:6
verses.text: These are the words of Irenaeus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:7
verses.text: But Papias himself in the preface to his discourses by no means declares that he was himself a hearer and eye-witness of the holy apostles, but he shows by the words which he uses that he received the doctrines of the faith from those who were their friends.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:8
verses.text: He says: "But I shall not hesitate also to put down for you along with my interpretations whatsoever things I have at any time learned carefully from the elders and carefully remembered, guaranteeing their truth.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:9
verses.text: For I did not, like the multitude, take pleasure in those that speak much, but in those that teach the truth; not in those that relate strange commandments, but in those that deliver the commandments given by the Lord to faith, and springing from the truth itself.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:10
verses.text: If, then, any one came, who had been a follower of the elders, I questioned him in regard to the words of the elders,—what Andrew or what Peter said, or what was said by Philip, or by Thomas, or by James, or by John, or by Matthew, or by any other of the disciples of the Lord, and what things Aristion and the presbyter John, the disciples of the Lord, say.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:11
verses.text: For I did not think that what was to be gotten from the books would profit me as much as what came from the living and abiding voice".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:12
verses.text: It is worth while observing here that the name John is twice enumerated by him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:13
verses.text: The first one he mentions in connection with Peter and James and Matthew and the rest of the apostles, clearly meaning the evangelist; but the other John he mentions after an interval, and places him among others outside of the number of the apostles, putting Aristion before him, and he distinctly calls him a presbyter.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:14
verses.text: This shows that the statement of those is true, who say that there were two persons in Asia that bore the same name, and that there were two tombs in Ephesus, each of which, even to the present day, is called John's.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:15
verses.text: It is important to notice this.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:16
verses.text: For it is probable that it was the second, if one is not willing to admit that it was the first that saw the Revelation, which is ascribed by name to John.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:17
verses.text: And Papias, of whom we are now speaking, confesses that he received the words of the apostles from those that followed them, but says that he was himself a hearer of Aristion and the presbyter John.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:18
verses.text: At least he mentions them frequently by name, and gives their traditions in his writings.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:19
verses.text: These things we hope, have not been uselessly adduced by us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:20
verses.text: But it is fitting to subjoin to the words of Papias which have been quoted, other passages from his works in which he relates some other wonderful events which he claims to have received from tradition.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:21
verses.text: That Philip the apostle dwelt at Hierapolis with his daughters has been already stated.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:22
verses.text: But it must be noted here that Papias, their contemporary, says that he heard a wonderful tale from the daughters of Philip.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:23
verses.text: For he relates that in his time one rose from the dead.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:24
verses.text: And he tells another wonderful story of Justus, surnamed Barsabbas: that he drank a deadly poison, and yet, by the grace of the Lord, suffered no harm.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:25
verses.text: The Book of Acts records that the holy apostles after the ascension of the Saviour, put forward this Justus, together with Matthias, and prayed that one might be chosen in place of the traitor Judas, to fill up their number.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:26
verses.text: The account is as follows: "And they put forward two, Joseph, called Barsabbas, who was surnamed Justus, and Matthias; and they prayed and said".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:27
verses.text: The same writer gives also other accounts which he says came to him through unwritten tradition, certain strange parables and teachings of the Saviour, and some other more mythical things.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:28
verses.text: To these belong his statement that there will be a period of some thousand years after the resurrection of the dead, and that the kingdom of Christ will be set up in material form on this very earth.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:29
verses.text: I suppose he got these ideas through a misunderstanding of the apostolic accounts, not perceiving that the things said by them were spoken mystically in figures.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:30
verses.text: For he appears to have been of very limited understanding, as one can see from his discourses.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:31
verses.text: But it was due to him that so many of the Church Fathers after him adopted a like opinion, urging in their own support the antiquity of the man; as for instance Irenaeus and any one else that may have proclaimed similar views.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:32
verses.text: Papias gives also in his own work other accounts of the words of the Lord on the authority of Aristion who was mentioned above, and traditions as handed down by the presbyter John; to which we refer those who are fond of learning.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:33
verses.text: But now we must add to the words of his which we have already quoted the tradition which he gives in regard to Mark, the author of the Gospel.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:34
verses.text: "This also the presbyter said: Mark, having become the interpreter of Peter, wrote down accurately, though not in order, whatsoever he remembered of the things said or done by Christ.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:35
verses.text: For he neither heard the Lord nor followed him, but afterward, as I said, he followed Peter, who adapted his teaching to the needs of his hearers, but with no intention of giving a connected account of the Lord's discourses, so that Mark committed no error while he thus wrote some things as he remembered them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:36
verses.text: For he was careful of one thing, not to omit any of the things which he had heard, and not to state any of them falsely".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:37
verses.text: These things are related by Papias concerning Mark.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:38
verses.text: But concerning Matthew he writes as follows: "So then Matthew wrote the oracles in the Hebrew language, and every one interpreted them as he was able".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:39
verses.text: And the same writer uses testimonies from the first Epistle of John and from that of Peter likewise.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:40
verses.text: And he relates another story of a woman, who was accused of many sins before the Lord, which is contained in the Gospel according to the Hebrews.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book III 39:41
verses.text: These things we have thought it necessary to observe in addition to what has been already stated.
